B000002UUX|5.0|Rust In Peace (1990.), Megadeth's fourth studio album<br /><br />Megadeth are without doubt one of the defining bands of thrash metal as well as one of the all time great metal bands. When Dave Mustaine was booted out of Metallica prior to the recording of 'Kill 'Em All' in 1983, no-one expected the guitarist to form a legendary band, despite his claims that his new band would be better than Metallica. Megadeth's rise to greatness though was one filled with problems and constant difficulties. The band abused alcohol and drugs in massive proportion and despite producing a great album in 'Peace Sells...' in 1986, suffered line up changes which destroyed the chemistry in the band (such as the firing of lead guitarist Chris Poland, who sold the band's equipment for drugs). In the midst of this, during the 1980's, Megadeth never quite found a truly stable and cohesive sound, despite putting out a fair share of good material. However, it all changed with the recruitment of guitar genius Marty Friedman and drummer Nick Menza at the end of the 1980's. Joining long time members Mustaine and bassist David Ellefson, the band went back to the studio and produced the album 'Rust In Peace', which was unleashed to the public in 1990. This album has gone on to become perhaps Megadeth's most praised album and is recognised as a thrash classic and defining moment in metal. So does this album deserve it's place as the album which immortalised Megadeth?<br /><br />The bottom line is that there are few albums which have conistency and excellency as 'Rust In Peace'. If Dave Mustaine's aim was to better his former band, he certainly matches them here. 'Rust In Peace' is a thrash album on par with works like '...And Justice For All' and 'Master Of Puppets', as well as other great thrash albums by other bands. Hell, this is one of the all time great metal albums! With 'Rust In Peace', an album who's title is inspired by the idea of destroying nuclear warheads and laying them to rust, is an album which works on many levels. All of the songs are excellent. The songs on the album are showcases of blisteringly fast riffs, awesome supporting bass lines, crazy solos and clever song structures. The thing I like most about the songwriting on the album is it's lack of standard format - one of the great things about Megadeth is they rarely follow standard verse, chorus song patterns on this album but instead serve up a more complex, intersting but seamless mix of verses, interludes solos and occasional grand choruses. This is highlighted in masterworks tracks like 'Holy Wars...The Punishement Due' and 'Five Magics'. Furthermore, the whole band are on top form. Mustaine serves up some lightning fast and deftly executed riffs and Dave Ellefson comes up with some clever bass lines (such as on 'Poison Was The Cure' and 'Dawn Patrol'). Menza's drumming is super fast too however perhaps the greatest performances come from Marty Friedman who plays some of the most inspired and interesting solos I've ever heard, on this album. 'Rust In Peace' is full of precise, musical masterwork.<br /><br />Currently, there are two CD versions of this album. The recent release is the new remaster of the album. I've got this version and personally think it is great. The bonus tracks included are welcome additions and the overall album sound quality is crisp and fresh, with all of the instrumentation standing out very clearly. However, some long time Megadeth fans have commented on the remixing of Mustaine's vocals. I personally have no problem with them (however, I've not heard the original release) but some long time fans of the album have spotted some edits and garbles when comparing to the original. Some listeners to this album may therefore want to consider getting the old CD version.<br /><br />Megadeth's 'Rust In Peace' kicks off with fan favourite song, 'Holy Wars...The Punishment Due', and what a song this is. Deservedly recognised as one of Megadeth's finest tunes, this songis awesome. Every time I hear this song, I'm left amazed by how much the band crams into the song - it's filled with loads of great riffs and solos. The song accelarates off at the start with a strong guitar assault before Mustaine's vocals, singing about the dangers of holy war begin. The song then cleverly flows into it's second half, courtesy of an acoustic interlude before more rounds of bone crunching verse. The guitar work towards the end of the song is phenominal, with a furious Mustaine solo and a climatic final verse. By now, if your listening to the album for the first time, your probably left speechless by the first song, however there is more great stuff to come. Another Megadeth fan favourite, 'Hangar 18' follows, a song about a futuristic military base. Opening with racing and heavy riffs, there are more great verses. However, it is the guitar solos which make this song truly amazing. The song exit has got not 1, not 2 but 7!! solos. It's a great sound. Another thrash staple in 'Take No Prisoners' follows; a shorter track, by no means inferior though. The song has a furious start, great call and response verse and a brilliant 'Take No Prisoners...Take No Shit' chorus at the end of the song which will rattle your speakers. One of my favourites on the album is next up, in the form of the highly underrated 'Five Magics'. David Ellefson's bass intro is awesome and is supplemented by screaming guitar work. The song has a catchy 'Give Me Alchemy...' chorus and again, like the songs before it, a mindblowing guitar exit.<br /><br />Another catchy bass intro opens up 'Poison Was The Cure', before a blistering drum bridge leads into the main part of the song, which is crazy! Marty Friedman plays some great riffs based on blues chords, at furious speeds. 'Lucretia' then follows, at the sound of an old womans cackle. This is another great thrash tune, with some pretty catchy guitar lines. Friedman and Mustaine plays more blistering solos and the end of the song. 'Tornado Of Souls' follows; another great song. The 'eye of tornado' chorus is a highlight, and the guitar work overall is first rate. The short length 'Dawn Patrol' is next. By no means filler, this is a song based on a memorable bass line from Ellefson with some intersting spoken words over the top. 'Rust In Peace...Polaris' then finishes the album on a punishing note. This is another brilliant song, a two part thrash attack, with a theme about nuclear war dominating the world. Commanding vocals and racing riffs set up a great song; the riffs cleverly change style mid-way through. Friedman plays yet another great solo at the end.<br /><br />...And there you have it; one of the greatest metal albums of all time. 'Rust In Peace' is a beast of an album and one that should definitely be not ignored. Megadeth are a pretty underrated band, often passed off as Metallica clones. The truth couldn't be further away from that opinion. Megadeth perfected their own sound with this album. 'Rust In Peace' is a rare album that combines consistency, with sheer attitude and raw power. Few metal albums succeed like this one...if you haven't got this album, make it your next CD purchace. A must own!!is song, I'm left amazed by how much the band crams into the song - it's filled with loads of great riffs and solos. The song accelarates off at the start with a strong guitar assault before Mustaine's vocals, singing about the dangers of holy war begin. The song then cleverly flows into it's second half, courtesy of an acoustic interlude before more rounds of bone crunching verse. The guitar work towards the end of the song is phenominal, with a furious Mustaine solo and a climatic final verse. By now, if your listening to the album for the first time, your probably left speechless by the first song, however there is more great stuff to come. Another Megadeth fan favourite, 'Hangar 18' follows, a song about a futuristic military base. Opening with racing and heavy riffs, there are more great verses. However, it is the guitar solos which make this song truly amazing. The song exit has got not 1, not 2 but 7!! solos. It's a great sound. Another thrash staple in 'Take No Prisoners' follows; a shorter track, by no means inferior though. The song has a furious start, great call and response verse and a brilliant 'Take No Prisoners...Take No Shit' chorus at the end of the song which will rattle your speakers. One of my favourites on the album is next up, in the form of the highly underrated 'Five Magics'. David Ellefson's bass intro is awesome and is supplemented by screaming guitar work. The song has a catchy 'Give Me Alchemy...' chorus and again, like the songs before it, a mindblowing guitar exit. Commanding vocals and racing riffs set up a great song; the riffs cleverly change style mid-way through. Friedman plays yet another great solo at the end.    ...And there you have it; one of the greatest metal albums of all time. 'Rust In Peace' is a beast of an album and one that should definitely be not ignored. Megadeth are a pretty underrated band, often passed off as Metallica clones. The truth couldn't be further away from that opinion. Megadeth perfected their own sound with this album. 'Rust In Peace' is a rare album that combines consistency, with sheer attitude and raw power. Few metal albums succeed like this one...if you haven't got this album, make it your next CD purchace. A must own!!

B00006JDU9|3.0|I was deeply dissappointed in Episode I because it does not even come close to the high quality of the legendary originals. There are many reasons for this, and one of the main reasons is the dumbing down of the Star Wars saga with childish elements such as the Barney-like Jar-Jar Binks which was an obvious attempt to draw in the younger crowd, thus increase gross revenue through mass-marketed merchandise, etc.<br /><br />Another reason why Episode I is a far cry from its predecessors is the extreme over-use of computer animation, which is supposed to compliment the movie and not replace the plot and character development that made the first 3 movies unforgettable. To me the puppets and costumes in the original felt far more real than any of the computer animation seen in the new movies.  The puppets made the story feel way more believable than computer animated aliens and robots. Don't get me wrong, I think digital effects can be great if used properly, but it shouldn't be the main ingredient in the recipe of movie making.<br /><br />Episode I lacked continuity and character development, which are major flaws that can't be ignored. It's a shame that Episode I was geared towards the younger generation and ignored the mature generation that the originals appealed to.<br /><br />One of the biggest problems with the movie is that it debunks the mythos surrounding the force by explaining it as some type of biological entities in the bloodstream by the name of midichlorians.  In one line delivered by Liam Neeson's character Qui-Gon Jinn, George Lucas who wrote the script single handedly destroyed the mystique that is the force, ironically a concept that he came up with originally nearly 3 decades ago.  Apparently Lucas forgot that part of what makes the original trilogy so special is that the force is an unknown, mysterious power that can be used for good or evil.  The fact that it is clouded in mystery and only a select few can tap into it is what made the concept so appealing, fostering imagination and dreams.  Lucas must have forgotten that this is Star Wars, not Star Trek, where the former is all about flights of fancy and mythology while the latter is more science oriented.<br /><br />Continuity was a major problem in Episode I, with sporadic jumps from scene to scene thereby breaking up any kind of depth to any of the characters, let alone allowing the story itself to develop.  Darth Maul in particular was perhaps the biggest disappointment since he had so much potential to be the next Darth Vader, or at least a villain close to Vader's status.  No such luck, he was as two-dimensional as they come, with no presence, no dialogue and barely any screen presence except the very end, and he dies before we have any idea of what his story was, or what kind of a character he was besides being \\"evil\\".  Even Qui-Gon Jinn was a let down, despite the fact that he was a very interesting character.  It's a paradox because the audience is given just a tiny bit of information about him, enough for people to like him, but no exposition to further his characteristics, it was minimal at best, so we are left with another intriguing character with a great deal of potential who was killed before we got a chance to really know him.<br /><br />Some scenes seemed to be superfluous such as the underwater part where Qui-Gon Jinn, Obi-Wan, and Jar-Jar Binks are inside a submarine vehicle, and they end up getting chased by a huge fish, which is swallowed by a bigger fish, and that fish is swallowed by an even bigger fish.  At that point I was convinced that Lucas had run out of good ideas for this film.<br /><br />The dialogue was wooden at best, with hardly any chemistry between any of the characters, except for Qui-Gonn and Obi-Wan.  Lucas seriously should have left the script writing up to far more talented screen writers.<br /><br />The excessive use of CGI has become Lucas' crutch, mistakenly believing that it can replace a solid story, deep characters and real sets.  It would have been so much better had Lucas used less computer animation and more props, costumes, puppets and animatronics, all of which have evolved a great deal in the past 3 decades and could have been put to much better use.  Less CGI please and more story, Lucas.<br /><br />Despite its flaws, the movie is interesting because it explains Anakin's origins, and some of the space battles as well as the Jedi lightsaber duels are truly impressive which redeem this film from being below average., deep characters and real sets.  It would have been so much better had Lucas used less computer animation and more props, costumes, puppets and animatronics, all of which have evolved a great deal in the past 3 decades and could have been put to much better use.  Less CGI please and more story, Lucas. <br /> <br />Despite its flaws, the movie is interesting because it explains Anakin's origins, and some of the space battles as well as the Jedi lightsaber duels are truly impressive which redeem this film from being below average.

B000E6UK5K|2.0|...and if you were actually stuck on a deserted island, this would be perfect music to watch the stars and drift off to sleep.     But this is also what happens when a rich artist gets fat, old, and content - a pleasant, mellow, inconsequential album lacking vitality or the inspiration to run its 52 minutes.      But we could all expect that from Gilmour. The problem with the fractalization of Pink Floyd, the most innovative and influential mainstream band the world ever knew, was that the sum was greater than the parts and now the parts just suffer for the imbalance and inability to create as the whole did.  Syd went loony-tunes and his solo stuff was appropriately interesting, unique and tripped out.  Roger was always the critical curmudgeon - the real soul and wit who had something to say and held the keys to the vision.  Gilmour was the spirit and the sound but was always content taking the listener to outer space dreamland. So that's what we get now - Roger gives us meaning but remains too earthbound with the sound while David gives us the meaningless sound and ambience with his head in the clouds.  Too much salt vs. too much sugar.     \\"Though the earth is dying his head is in the stars...out of touch he'll live in wonder\\" - from track 9, sounds like Roger criticizing David    This moodpiece depends on one's state of mind to be appreciated.  If you want to relax and float away, then you'll agree with all the glowing reviews.  If you want some meat and gristle on your music, then you'll give up before the halfway point.  It's all very beautiful or all incredibly boring, depending on you.      Castellorizon: whatever intro  On An Island: breathtaking  The Blue: beautiful, with gorgeous soloing and ridiculously godawful lyrics  Take A Breath: solid uptempo  Red Sky At Night: classic Floyd interlude   This Heaven: moderately enjoyable, lightweight bluesy jangle   Then I Close My Eyes: aptly named, this is just fluff, or beautiful depending   Smile: sickeningly sweet, or beautiful depending  A Pocketful Of Stones: to quote the poet, \\"There's no there there.\\"  Where We Start: wistful closer    Gilmour shouldn't be criticized for being happy and being who he is.  But this is still mostly mediocre imo. Happiness and contentment are not the greatest catalysts for art. Listen to Donald Fagen's new one for a lesson in growing old not gracefully into Alzheimerland but growing old vitally and relevantly, with juices flowing freely, no wasted notes, no meandering. That one sounds necessary. This one does not.  Burn, borrow, or steal, but don't buy.        [the more i listen the more it has become a 3-star}

I still had no clue that this was out til I was strolling through Target last week I didnt know that he was mainstream now...its usually the backselfs of my local vinyl shop to find them. now that thats out of the way. the album can be summed up in one word idealy. B0000AXE8I|3.0|At first I was impressed by 'The Matrix Reloaded', by the sheer visual quality, but the story left much to be desired, as in the story felt quite weak compared to the first. This movie felt more as a showcase for special effects than a worthy sequel, way too 2-dimensional in retrospect, not enough character development.  The new characters introduced adding nothing worthwhile, such as Niobe, Link, Ice, Ballard, Seraph, Persephone, and Merovingian.  After the movie, how much do we know about each character?  Next to nothing, so it doesn't really further the plot line that much, hence they are little more than window dressing.  The Wachowski brothers became overly ambitious with this project and simply tried to do too much with too little time.  In the original there were a few characters but at least there was enough time devoted to fleshing out their personas so we grew to know and care about them, whereas in this sequel the characters that we enjoyed from the first one they take a backseat to new, inconsequential and pointless characters that have as much depth as cardboard cutouts.<br /><br />Several plot elements seemed superfluous, like Persephone and the Marovingian.  Along with Seraph, it became obvious that these characters were simply added to increase the amount of mythological, religious and philosophical references, and once enough of them were added the idea seemed to be that a story would develop as a result.  Unfortunately the only thing it all added up to was an incohesive, sporadic storyline interweaved with several superb action sequences, but that does not make a classic like the first one.<br /><br />Its predecessor 'The Matrix' is a classic because it combined a variety of influences from anime, movies, comics, philosophy and religion and created its own mythology while the sequel attempted to throw in way too many historical references and thereby hoping to make the story even more fantastic, but it simply ended up diluting the greatness of the original film.  'Reloaded' was too busy with too many themes with the thought that more is better, but as the first film proved less is more within the context.<br /><br />The difference between the original and this sequel is that the first one made its money and cult following based on word of mouth, because of the quality of the elements involved. This sequel on the other hand has made far more money, but that is based on an even bigger budget and massive ad-campaigns that put recent Star Wars film ads to shame, and hype rather than substance.<br /><br />'The Matrix Reloaded' is not a bad film, although it's not great either. I did enjoy it, but it's just not up to par with the first.  The Wachowski brothers would have been better off with their artistic integrity intact had they just stuck with the original and never made any sequels.  Few people know that the sequels were only made based on the tremendous success of the first film, there was never a whole trilogy planned.  The studios as well as the Wachowskis saw the opportunity to milk the cash cow, and it shows.<br /><br />This film works as a good action film, but it pales in comparison to the philosophy and handling of the religious subtext seen in the original 'Matrix'.the original film. B00000IAU3|4.0|So let me get this straight.  Girl wakes up hung over on a dismal rainy day, misses the bus and is late for work (a job she can't stand and risks losing), but then she gets a phone call from her BF and discovers \\"it's not so bad,\\" in fact, \\"it's the best day of [her] life.\\"  Ah, youth--when love is all!  You think today is good, Dido baby, just wait til the weekend!!!  You'll be in heaven, even if you are no angel.    OK, so it's a slight song in many ways.  But like most of the tracks on NO ANGEL, \\"Thank You\\" ultimately wins you over with its matter-of-fact romanticism.  There's a dreamy, languid quality to \\"Thank You,\\" the album's US hit single, that makes you think, \\"Yeah, if I were her boss, I probably WOULD fire her, but if it got her into the music biz all the sooner, I'd be doing her (and the world at large) a favor.    I actually had not really heard much of Dido's (& Co.'s)work until recently.  But I had enjoyed \\"Thank You,\\" thank you very much.  And when I recently saw a posting on a fansite dedicated to the late great Laura Nyro, referring to Dido as some kind of poseur (poseuse?), I had to wonder if this wasn't yet another case of putting one artist down in order to build another one up.  Few singer songwriters will ever achieve the brilliance of Laura Nyro at her best: she was an absolute genius.  I don't think Dido is quite on that level, at least not yet, but in her cool, ethereal way she does offer a unique take on some of the same themes of love, loss and loneliness that Nyro addressed almost 40 years ago now.  The cool, ethereal, sometimes detached Dido may seem lightyears away from the fiery, passionate Nyro circa ELI & THE 13TH CONFESSION.  But strip away all the electronica and you have the same kind of intense confessionalism that writers like Nyro and Joni Mitchell introduced audiences to in the late 60s and early 70s.    Some will find Dido's brand of confessional songwriting a little solipsistic.  The first track has her desperately yearningfor a lost love, the second, on the other hand, has her feeling confined and stifled in a love relationship. And so it goes, from the obsessive to the oppressive.  But that's called--at least in some circles--being in your 20s (which she still was at the time this album was cut).  It's a forgiveable human flaw, and not an unacceptable one in a songwriter just starting out, provided she offers the occasional leavening touch. (One should also keep in mind that the narrator of any given song may not always be identical with the songwriter: she may be adopting a persona here and there).  But too many songs in the first person, can get to be a little much, I admit.  So much so that the listener is grateful for a song like \\"Isobel,\\" a sad tune presumably about a friend's painful decision to abort.    Aside from that brief excursion into the third person (well, actually, it's in the second person but it FEELS like third), however, the \\"leavening touch\\" most often employed here is Dido's attention to detail on \\"Thank You\\" and elswhere.  On the single, for instance, the details give the song a sense of place and an emotional authenticity that belies the coolness of the arrangements.  It's more prose than poetry, but it's striking prose.    And speaking of the arrangements, well, listening to this record, I kept thinking, \\"So this must be this 'trip hop' I keep hearing about.\\"   Well, there are plenty of beats in the overall dreamy mix, but the musical settings the singer has come up with in collaboration with her brother Rollo and other collaborators ultimately seem more \\"trippy\\" than \\"hoppy.\\"  Which makes for a perfect late night listening experience.

0757302661|5.0|It is now three days since I gave birth to my first baby, a beautiful 9lb girl. In my last few weeks of pregnancy I met a neighbor who insisted I read this book as soon as I could. She described the hypnobirthing philosophy of birth with no pain or fear and how she had used it successfully with her third child. I was skeptical that it could help me much because I had heard that first babies were more difficult to deliver than second or third babies, and I thought maybe her success was due to her previous experiences with labor. Regardless, I decided to buy the book. When it arrived a few days later I skimmed through it and attempted some of the breathing techniques. I found them very difficult because my lung capacity at 9 months pregnant was pretty low. The accompanying CD, however, was very easy to use and I got sort-of addicted to it (only the relaxation part) because it helped me get back to sleep when I woke up at 4am every morning. It taught me to relax my entire body instantly, with the idea that this could help me through contractions. It also improved my breathing technique somewhat. When labor came I was able to use my relaxation skills to work through early, active, and transition labor stages with relatively little pain and a strong sense of control over my body. I was happy and thought I would get through everything fine until the pushing stage. I had not read or practiced any hypnobirthing techniques for pushing and, unfortunately relaxation was not an option. My pushing was intensely difficult and there was most certainly pain and fear. I believe, however, that had I discovered hypnobirthing earlier and practiced all the breathing techniques, I may have had an easier time. Even though my pushing stage was hard, I didn't tear and I didn't require any medication, stiches, or other interventions. I plan to recommend hypnobirthing to all my pregnant friends early in their pregnancies, based on my strongly positive experience and will use it from the get go myself if I am ever pregnant again.

The use of analog synths brought the band new ideas about the songs. Producer, Ben Hillier (Doves, Blur, Elbow, etc) was not a big fan of DM. This element was a key for the recording of the album. He didn't have preconceptions about the previous records or how the songs should sound. He worked really fast and after a couple of weeks according to the band, they noticed the direction of the songs. Depeche Mode don't work like most of the bands. When they get together to make an album they have very complete ideas songwise. Playing the angel is the first record in  Depeche Mode history which contains 3 songs penned by singer Dave Gahan (Suffer well, Nothing's impossible and I want it all). B000AJJNPY|5.0|I've been extremely engrossed by \\"&Aacute;gtis Byrjun\\" and \\"( )\\" before. &Aacute;gtis Byrjun was one of the stepping stones for my entire discovery of post-rock. It was probably the most unique music I've ever heard at that point. ( ) had a great concept, was a great follow-up and a re-defined sound for the band but 2 or 3 songs on the second half were dragged on a little too long for me. But this... is a whole new level of Sigur Ros' unimaginable talent of creating out-of-this-world, or galaxy, even... sound. They have ironed out the very few flaws from before and have truly achieved nirvana here.<br /><br />The first song, \\"Takk...\\" is a simple, two-minute angelic, ambient intro.<br /><br />Next is \\"Glosoli,\\" a rather relaxing track for the majority of the duration, with light, alien-like vocals, floating bells, and a strange faint marching kind of sound for rhythm, painting a nostalgic, child-like image (maybe the video is giving me that image, but...). About two-thirds into the song, the intense buildup is foreshadowed and all of a sudden that powerful, heavier rock sound is released, creating that familiar yet refreshing transcendent sound that no other musicians can produce.<br /><br />Next is \\"Hoppipolla,\\" starting out with a simple piano melody, soon adding string instruments for a very welcoming, uniting feeling. I have no idea what he is saying but that has no bearing that this is some of the most joyful music I've ever heard, and delivers such a warm feeling despite the origin is the frigid lands of Iceland. This song is shorter and has a bit more structure than most Sigur Ros songs. \\"Meo Blodnasir\\" feels like it is the ending to the previous song; it has the exact same sounds, not sure why it is split up.<br /><br />\\"Se Lest\\" begins with some distorted electronic bleeps which slowly morphs into a delicate, nostalgic, icy melody of bells, quickly introducing that familiar, alien-like light vocal style and starts overlapping itself. Some brass instruments suddenly emerge for a little twist after a period of extreme ambience. It's a very quirky addition to an otherwise very laid-back song. However that will start paving the way for the splash of genius that is the next song...<br /><br />\\"Saeglopur\\" is probably my favorite song on the album and it seems like most agree. It begins with a delicate, somewhat cold piano melody quickly adding vocals, bells and very idiosyncratic, playful little percussion. This continues on for a minute or so, gets you used to the sound which is reminiscent of the long track before, then the piano melody suddenly backflips into something more menacing and darker, and ascends into a heavy wall of arcane sound with the wailing vocals and general melody staying the same if you listen closely. The vocals here are truly phenomenal as they soar just as far from our galaxy as the rest of the music. Just when you think the song will come crashing back down, it retains that phantasmal feeling for most of the song. After a while, the wall of arcane sound is overcome and the music gradually calms down into a limbo between the heavy side and soft side, and slowly fades out. Absolutely brilliant.<br /><br />\\"Milano\\" takes its time to emerge, introducing the next joyful melody the band has concocted. It kind of reminds me of Virar vel til Loft&aacute;r&aacute;sa, a melody that basically continues on for 10 minutes, but it's so good it doesn't get old. It also keeps changing from upbeat to calm, with the perfect buildups of course, but I'd say the majority of the song is quite relaxing.<br /><br />\\"Gong\\" is my second favorite song, a slightly different style than the rest. It begins with a simple string melody for about 10 seconds to point the listener in the wrong direction, and then starts to introduce the main theme. The majority of the song has a very upbeat and fractious rhythm, and more straightforward vocals expressing a darker feeling instead of such a joyful fuzzy feeling like most songs.There are so many different sounds intertwined and interweaved together here it is really a much needed change of pace and a puzzle for your ears to unravel. My only complaint is the song isn't long enough. It's so good I usually play it twice in a row.<br /><br />\\"Andvari\\" ...this song is very soothing and hypnotic... so much that the entire song just went by and I didn't write a single word during it and it was over all of a sudden. \\"Svo Hljott\\" is another very calming song. The entire song is one big crescendo, like weather going from a dull, foggy, cold morning to a sunny and warm afternoon. \\"Heys&aacute;tan\\" ends the album with a satisfied feeling... doesn't end with a bang, doesn't really fade out softly, but a happy medium.<br /><br />If you're new to Sigur Ros... I think it's obvious that the band is very much an acquired taste. I remember finding the hype of Sigur Ros on Amazon.com and listening to Svefn-g-englar a few times and absolutely hating it. A few months later &Aacute;gtis Byrjun was in my hands. You've got to give them an honest chance and you'll be happy when you do.different sounds intertwined and interweaved together here it is really a much needed change of pace and a puzzle for your ears to unravel. My only complaint is the song isn't long enough. It's so good I usually play it twice in a row. <br /> <br />\\"Andvari\\" ...this song is very soothing and hypnotic... so much that the entire song just went by and I didn't write a single word during it and it was over all of a sudden. \\"Svo Hljott\\" is another very calming song. B000066F6H|3.0|I don't know why this album in particular has instigated this tirade from me but for some reason all the bad reviews have really pissed me off.  For whatever reason I'm in the habit of reading the lowest rated reviews of albums I like first.  Usually I just laugh at the ignorant fools who say stuff like, \\"The Velvet Underground is the most over rated band in history,\\" and you won't find a more vigorous Velvets defender than me.  But the handful of lousy reviews for this album, which I don't even give 4 stars myself, really made me mad. <br />First of all, I think that in 2006 it's really idiotic to dismiss a band because they sound like another band.  So the Hives are obviously derivative of the MC5, the Kinks, Da Stooges, etc. and those bands did it first and better.  Of course they did... THEY'RE THE F**KING MC5!  But you know what?  The MC5 hasn't made any new music since 1971.  So any band that worships them as much as I do is cool with me.  As long as they don't rip off riffs directly I'm ok with \\"derivative\\".  Because if you like that old-school crummy rock it's hard to come by and you should be dying for more.  Besides in this day and age it's almost impossible to NOT be derivative of something (before you jump down my throat, I know there are exceptions: Flaming Lips, Sonic Youth, Tom Waits - off the top of my head).  As long as it's done right, with the appropriate reverence/humor, it's perfectly acceptable to wear your influences on your sleeve. <br />Secondly, when people complain that a 30 minute rock album is a rip off because it's too short just tells me that those idiots have absolutely no understanding of rock-n-roll at all let alone the history of the music business.  You see, in the glory days before Compact Discs destroyed music 30 - 40 minutes was the most music you could cram on an LP without losing fidelity.  More than that and you had to either cram the grooves so close you lost sound or you had to move it on to a second LP which was prohibitively expensive.  That's part of the reason some of those first 2 lp albums are real classics, i.e. The White Album, Exile on Maine Street, Blonde On Blonde. [Actually the White Album is a bad example because it was the first album on Apple Records but you get my point.]  In order to convince the label to put out two LPs you really had to have something to say.  Otherwise your album got cut to fit the medium, therefore you left the weaker songs off the record.  The CD's 75 minute format allowed artists to become very poor self-editors.  Whatever crap they recorded got slapped on the CD.  Rarely is there a 75, or even 60 minute album that is good all the way through but, now, the music buying public, in true American-Consumer fashion, has come to demand quantity over quality.  \\"If I'm going to spend $18 on a CD I better be getting 75 minutes of music even if 45 minutes of that is pabulum I'll never listen to.\\"  (For a few years a backlash to this has been building, hence the success of iTunes.)   <br />Anyway, my long rambling point is that - More Is Rarely Better!  The Hives' 30 Minute Veni Vidi Vicious is the perfect length.  No filler.  No tedious solos that need to be skipped over.  The longest song clocks in at 3:22; no time to get bored here.  Just 12 short kick-ass examples of garage rock in almost it's purest form.  I say \\"almost\\" because, despite what some reviewers here say, this album is overproduced.  Personally, I really cherish that recorded-in-my-parent's-basement kind of feel to my crappy rock records; this album is obviously meant to be a little bit more radio friendly.  I can't fault them for that but it's just not my thing. <br />Bottom line is that this is a fun record and I think that a majority of the reviews have missed this point.  If you understand that when I call some music \\"crappy\\" I don't necessarily mean it derogatorily or if you appreciate Lenny Kaye's Nuggets Collection or if you have a collection of cherished 45s you bought at local rock shows then I trust this album will make you smile.  No, it's not as good as the MC5 or the Stooges or what ever high water marks you want set for Rock... But what is?  If you can't get over that I can only suggest your life would be much happier if you get off that pretentious pole you've got lodged in your rectum.

0553579908|4.0|This is the second book in his \\"Song of Fire and Ice\\" series, which now appears to be going to run at least five thick books, since the fourth one, A Feast of Crows, recently appeared and doesn't conclude it. It keeps things going, and indeed it's a clash of kings, since no fewer than six claimants to crowns are involved: Joffrey, the nominal son of Robert, the previous king (though actually the bastard of the queen and her twin brother); Stannis and Renley, the previous king's brothers, each of whom claims the throne, Stannis by primogeniture and Renley by popularity; Daenerys, the daughter and only surviving child of the king whose throne Robert had usurped; in the north only Robb, the heir to Winterfell whose ancestors had ruled the north before Daenerys' ancestors had united the continent; and Balon, Lord of the Iron Islands and self-proclaimed king of whatever he can hold. Nothing much terribly new happens in this book, except that Stannis, through his wife, has come under the influence of a priestess of an eastern religion who also has strong magical powers. That provides a religious edge to the conflict that wasn't really present in the first book; true, some people worshipped the Seven in One, and others the Old Gods, but both faiths had a live-and-let-live attitude toward the other. But R'hllor, the Heart of Fire, claims to be the only God and wishes to end worship of any other, by force if necessary (and often as a first choice). (Something familiar there...) Otherwise-well, there's lots of military maneuvering, lots of political intrigue, and lots of pain to a lot of people, though not much to the aristocracy. POV characters are mostly the same as in the first book, although there are two new ones-Davos, a former smuggler and now a top aide to Stannis, and Theon, a former foster-ling of Lord Eddard of Winterfell and the son of Balon. However, I think both of them are dead by the end of the book-Theon for sure, and Davos probably. Even as a fast reader with a good bit of time to read one of these books takes me a good while to finish; with appendices it's over 1000 pages. Not too easy to handle, either. But good writing, good characters, and an interesting story. And I don't get the padded feeling that I do from a lot of Long novels; all the events advance the plot.h a good bit of time to read one of these books takes me a good while to finish; with appendices it's over 1000 pages. B000002MIY|5.0|Most of the reviews here focus on the music. I well remember my first day of playing the album, more than 12 years ago now, I was focussing on the music too.  The lyrics - well, just a bit of fun weren't they - so I thought.  Then, on about the 8th play of the album that day, the meaning of the lyrics suddenly hit me and by the 12th play I was knocked out.  So for the unitiated reviewers above who find such titles as Snowbound and Tomorrow's Girls merely \\"amusing\\", here's what it's all about. Trans-Island Skyway sets the scene. The guy has just lost the girl.  He has to escape. He's in pieces and the only way out is make-believe.  But that sort of thing you can't get out your head.  He's hardly begun his magic journey in the Kamakiriad when there she is, by the side of the road. There's been an accident. She's the beautiful survivor - and in his imagination, he sees himself lying injured on the road.  He has to take her along with her on this journey through pain. 'Get in Snakehips', he says. 'Strap in tight'. We've got to make that final deadline.  We'll be deep in the Zone by crying time. Countermoon, the next song, is about tragedy.  The moon is the symbol of love and the countermoon is that which destroys love.  The street is slick with tears, a countermoonbeam  strikes and she says \\"You're not my Johnny - my Johnny was the best\\". Only the countermoon can make girls so heartless and guys so restless.  Springtime carries on the journey further into the escape of illusion.  This time it's distorting mirrors. Life has becomes absurd, a joke. You look into the mirrors and scan yourself for memories of past loves, memories which might ease the pain. But nothing does. The next track, Snowbound, is about ice - the ice inside. Put on your thermasuit. Protect yourself from the ice. We're going to trick and trash and have some fun. But then the critic tells us that this work is seducing us with light.  No way - you can't fool yourself. The ice is there.  Some (other) loser out on the frozen river fires a flare and for seven seconds its Christmas - but for only seven seconds. Tommorows Girls is about how the guys fall so easily for the girls on the grass at lunch hour - a little smile can make your day.  But watch out - they're not real girls - their tomorrow's girls.  Look out fellows - it's shredding time and it's your heart that's going to get shredded. And the truth is, all girls are Tomorrow's girls. Watch out guys - you've got no chance. Shades of Jaques Brel's 'Les Filles et les Chiens'. On the Dunes tells us how it all happened.  There they were, down on the dunes, everything seemed fine. Then, a countermoonbeam struck - it was like homicide on the dunes.  Pretty women with lovers by their side, it's like an awful dream. It's rough on the dunes. The final track on the album, Teahouse on the Tracks, is the resolution, the end of the journey, the way out of pain. You're in Flytown, as far down as you can ever get, where hope and the highway end. But it's music (what else would you expect) that is the saviour.  The Siegel Bros with Irene, Flocko and litle Amy Khan leading off the big front line.  You get a case of party feet and then the ice inside begins to crack.  Next morning you're back at the wheel, calm, crisp and strong.  The Teahouse on the Tracks was your last chance and you took it. You learnt how to dance again. So there it is. Donald Fagan - not only a musical genius but a lyrical genius as well. <br />

B00005JKES|4.0|Missed this series when it originally aired and, even though this is the `complete' first season of TWIN PEAKS, I still haven't seen the pilot episode.  Lacking those warm and fuzzy first-wave memories I'm at a bit of a loss accounting for the series' cult status.  What with its melodramatic feuds and prodigious bed-hopping this one, fifteen years on, looks an awful lot like such contemporary prime-time soaps as Dynasty, Dallas, Falcon Crest, and their ilk.  I don't intend to track down any of those titles soon, but then they don't carry the cult cachet of David Lynch's brainchild.<br /><br /> The meat of the story, of course, is the investigation of the murder of young Laura Palmer.  The local authorities and a G-man team up to solve the mystery.  Along the way they uncover, or at least the audience discovers, the sometimes seamy underbelly of an all-American small town located somewhere in the Great Northwest.<br /><br />Beyond the missing pilot episode you do get your money's worth out of this set.  Every episode contains a commentary track by a crew member - usually a director (none by Lynch, though,) sometimes a cinematographer or writer.  There's too much over-the-shoulder exposition going on to really call this one wild, wacky, bizarre, or whatever it was I was expecting.  The best episode is the third one, the only one on the set directed by Lynch, entitled `Zen, or the Skill to Catch a Killer.'  This is the episode that contains The Man From Another Place, a short, backward-talking man in a dream room filled with red curtains.  It's a well-known scene, very well done.  Somehow I thought the series was loaded with such bizarre scenes, but that's about it for the really weird.  Kyle MacLachlan has a good, wholesome creepy quality that befits his FBI special agent character, a pre-X-Files fed who solves the crime as much by intuition as by deduction and who really savors a good cup of coffee. The breathtakingly beautiful Sherilyn Fenn also stands out in this strong ensemble cast.  Overall an enjoyable, somewhat eccentric, series.n this strong ensemble cast.   Overall an enjoyable, somewhat eccentric, series.   <br />

B00005I44H|5.0|Murray Perahia was quite a young man when he started his cycle as both pianist and conductor in the Mozart concertos. He was followed by another superb Mozartean, Mitsuko Uchida, whose cycle on Philips features the same English Chamber Orchestra, so I thought it might be worthwhile to compare the two.<br /><br />Perahia:  Perahia is a thougtful, non-virtuosic, and highly musical pianist. He was at his most extroverted in these works, thereby escaping any tendency to make Mozart sound precious or dainty. Although he had never conducted a recording before, he also proved  a vigorous leader from the keyboard (not exceeding Bernstein in this dual role, but Bernstein only made a handful of concerto recordings). The orchestral accompaniments are vivacious, if a bit straightforward. Perahia saves his musical insights for the keyboard in large part, and here he excels. His interpretations are flawless, full of invention. The recorded sound, especially in early installments, can be rough, however, resulting in a somewhat shallow, bright, and brittle piano. As listed here at Amazon there is an enormous price difference (2-to-1 or more) between this 12-disc set and Uchida's 9-disc one, but at other retailers and on the used market both can be bought very cheaply.<br /><br />Uchida: From the rapturous reviews below, you would think Perahia has no rivals in this music. He does, of course, in Clifford Curzon, Clara Haskil, Rudolf Serkin (though not the late, enfeebled recordings on DG), and Uchida herself, to mention only a few. Uchida first made her mark by recording the complete Mozart sonatas. Here she is joined by a talented ocnductor, Jeffrey Tate, who may be a deciding factor for some buyers since his accompaniments are more polished and detailed than Perahia's. Philips also gives the ECO and the piano better sound,  with more warmth and depth than we hear from Perahia. As an itnerpreter, Uchida is more studied--her phrasing can be affected compared to Perahia's--but in general she is to the manner born. This is immpeccable playing, and her ability to shape a lyrical phrase bows to no one. Uchida's complete cycle sells for under $65 at Amazon and much cheaper than that on the used market.<br /><br />I found while collecting these great works that both Uchida and Perahia were completely satisfying--modern and fresh without resorting to period-performance mannerisms--and on any given day I liked one as much as the other. However, the advantage of having a good conductor and better sound is undeniably in Uchida's favor, while Perahia's more natural, extroverted style gives him an advantage. We are fortunate to have two compellling cycles at mid-price.the manner born. This is immpeccable playing, and her ability to shape a lyrical phrase bows to no one. Uchida's complete cycle sells for under $65 at Amazon and much cheaper than that on the used market.    I found while collecting these great works that both Uchida and Perahia were completely satisfying--modern and fresh without resorting to period-performance mannerisms--and on any given day I liked one as much as the other. However, the advantage of having a good conductor and better sound is undeniably in Uchida's favor, while Perahia's more natural, extroverted style gives him an advantage. We are fortunate to have two compellling cycles at mid-price.

I loved it!  Yes, the commentary by William Shatner and his daughter helped me understand the stress and pressure they were under just to make the film.  The budget cuts, the studio suggesting dialogue cuts and inserts, the time constraints and Shatner's original vision not coming to life all contribute to a film that when first viewed are obvious problems.  But, upon 2nd viewing the film has taken on a more topical and ironic parallel with what's happening in our world today.  I was mesmerized by the whole story and situation in which the characters found themselves.  The dialogue between the principles was humorous and was some of the best in the series.   <br /> <br />Budget was cut for the special effects, but they weren't awful as so many reviewers have stated.  They just didn't look like they used the current techniques that were available to special effect films at that time.  They looked more like they used a process used in the 50's and 60's.  <br /> <br />  The film as a whole works on many levels.  Flawed?  Yes.  As bad as they say?  No!  I found it funny, charming, exciting, topical, profound, moving and satisfying.  Give it one more chance.  I'm glad I did!

Crystal clear picture and sound, great packaging and graphics, awesome booklet. Included in the special features is a terrific commentary track, one of the best I've heard covering every aspect of the film, Kurosawa, Japanese history and Japanese film history.    Great story about a double filling in the shoes of Samurai Warlord Takeda Shingen. Shingen was a brilliant warrior and politican who still is very popular in Japan today. If not for his tragic early demise, he may have been the one to unify Japan as Shogun. Instead his death led to Nobunaga's rise and subsequently the rise of the Tokugawa shogunate which rule for 300 years. Japan may indeed be a very different place if it was a Takeda dynasty. It is still a mystery today way Shingen died.  Back to the film, it has pageantry, epic battles, action and drama galore, even if you hate a history lesson, the movie will hold you captive.     The only negative I could consider is its somewhat stagy, slow opening act...I loved this scene, especial since most of it was new to me (not in original U.S. release) but someone new to Japanese film might find it dull going and give up on the film before the momentum builds. You don't have to wait long, it starts building in the next scene!    A great movie, in complete form,  presented in near pristine condition by a film master in top form. This is a 5 star release at any price! For those of you complaining about the price...rent it!

I am talking especially about the last few tracks. When you listen to them, you feel very, very engrossed. You are literally rooted to the stop. You stop whatever you are doing (if possible) and just listen to the beating of the drums. You listen to the choir in the foreground and you stir in you seat as the shivers seize you. There is something about the combination of beauty, elegance, and sheer power that makes you hit the repeat button over and over.<br /><br />The only compliant I have with this soundtrack is that it does have a Zimmer flare. It is very similar to the Gladiator music and the Pirates of the Carribbean soundtrack (probably because Zimmer and Badelt are good friends and all three use the Hollywood Symphony Orchestra.) In fact, all three are only distinguished by their overall tones. Samurai is Japanese, Pirates, well, pirate-ish, and Gladiator...gladiator.<br /><br />I highly recommend this soundtrack because it is my favorite over the three excellent LOTR soundtracks and is even threatening to usurp the outstanding Finding Neverland. Buy this soundtrack. Even if you aren't a fan of orchestral music, you'll enjoy this CD. It sends shivers down your spine.

B000E1155O|5.0|Some of us here whose proclivities gravitate towards rare psych and folk have been bemoaning the recent flurry of \\"buried treasures\\" and \\"lost classics\\". It seems a day does not go by without a new release or re-issue of a forgotten or recently discovered artist rescued from obscurity passing before our attentive eyes and drooling mouths. Sometimes the \\"lost classic\\" status is not always deserved (not everything made in the sixties and seventies that didn't receive any attention is noteworthy, somethings are better off staying buried or lost), but it's sure keeping the reissue labels and revisionist musicologists busy as they map out an ever-growing expanse of the spheres of influence on music today. It's hard to keep up and also pay equal attention to all the great music that is being made right now.  <br /> <br />This makes me very happy on the one hand that amazing music continues to be discovered but it also drives me crazy us to see my paycheck quickly dwindling every week. Why just in the past month, I've seen re-issues from Bridget St. John, Kay Hoffman, John Jacob Niles, Kaleidoscope and Fairfield Parlour (all pretty amazing!) among others. And now on my plate are these previously unreleased home recordings of German underground folk singer, Sibylle Baier.  <br /> <br />I must admit when I first heard this, I suspected fraud. These recordings sound almost too contemporary to have been made in the early seventies. But after doing a little research, I found out this is no fraud. These intimate recordings fully deserve their \\"buried treasure\\" status, for whatever that's worth at this point. Baier, only previously known for a song on an early Wim Wenders film soundtrack, recorded these songs in her home from 1970-73 after a \\"spirit-renewing\\" trip through the Swiss Alps. She has the warm Sunday jam and tea voice reminiscent of Vashti Bunyan, but with the more spare guitar compositions and melancholy vocal delivery of someone like Chan Marshall. In fact, I sort ofwish the new Cat Power or Beth Orton records were this good! Like Bunyan, Baier shunned what could have been a successful career in order to raise a family and it's because of her son, Robby, that these recordings are being heard at all. But unlike Bunyan, these songs don't derive from a back to nature hippie-folk aesthetic, but rather they come from a more delicate fragility where life's beauty and despair are interwoven with the tiny details of daily life. Beautiful! Totally recommended for seventies folk enthusiasts as well as fans of contemporary singer/song-writers.

034544678X|4.0|Do you think that all books written by a Ph.D. need to be dryly academic and plainly boring? Well, it tends to happen, but this is clearly not the case.    Patricia McConnell has managed to write a highly entertaining and informative book on dogs, their gestures, their favorite activities (and, no, hugging is not one of them), their social needs, and their character. She has cleverly combined her knowledge on the subject with her love for dogs in this unusual book filled with anecdotes and stories from her own experience.    This book clearly describes the main differences between our primate behavior and our dogs' instincts, the kind of differences that usually lead to frustrated owners and mischievous pets. Learning about them will help you better communicate with your dog, understand her reactions, and also prevent potential problems with your neighbors. For example, shouting does not prevent your dog from barking, it just tells your dog that you are joining her in her arousal...

B00005B36H|4.0|Well, it might seem strange that I am giving a Tool album only 4 stars, being a fan and rating the first two - Undertow and Aenima - with five. You know, I used to think for quite a long time that Tool is the best band ever, but now I merely think that they are the best band in 1990's metal. They surely are brilliant and worth all the praise (combining such depth and expression with energy and sensitivity of alternative metal), but they are not gods (and the band themselves are perfectly aware of it, just read the lyrics carefully).  <br />I would like to draw some comparisons that come to my mind when speaking about Tool. Firstly, with Radiohead. Undertow and Aenima could be compared to the Bends and OK Computer, with Undertow being a straightforward, monolithic piece of art dominated by guitars and the following album, Aemina, being a true masterpiece, on a level with OK Computer, sprawling and multi-sided, touching the deepest topics that may come to a mind of a person (not that Undertow and the Bends aren't masterpieces in their own right). Radiohead's music is certainly more melodic and finds more public appeal, but metalheads would obviously prefer Tool. <br />The next band that comes to mind is Joy Division and Unknown Pleasures - Closer pair. What unites these bands most is perhaps perfect balance between the four members of each of them, then, of course, the darkness and gloom (but in the end, the music of both is cathartic, tragic and optimistic). But as we know with Joy Division,  the singer, Ian Curtis, killed himself short after recording Closer. I personally think he understod that with such an album, the band simply had nowhere else to go as it had reached the final and the best possible destination. <br />Radiohead solved that dilemma - after releasing their perfect album, OK Computer, - with detouring into arty, weird electro-tinged rock. Tool released Lateralus, which took an eternity to record, but leaves the feeling as the band, however talentedand inspired they are, is trying too hard and the result was an album somehow too complex, too mathematical and so on. <br />Not that Lateralus is bad - it is a good album, very good indeed. Tool fans and those who feel interest in deep and esoteric music will enjoy it, and I also did. There are all the elements of Tool's greatness, but stripped down (or overemphasized?): deep lyrics, great instrumentation, dynamics and tempo changes. Some tracks are great, like the Grudge, Schism, Parabola, Ticks and Leeches, also Disposition and Reflection. Others, however, may feel too long and a bit boring. <br />I am still looking forward to Tool's new album, hoping it will be more vital and interesting. Thank you for attention.

B00005U11Z|5.0|I've been collecting live dvd's from many of my old favorite rock bands from the 80's and 90's, and this recent addition is probably one of the best I own. <br /> <br />The audio is stunning in terms of clarity and power, the 5:1 mix rocks, especially if you have a powerful home theater set up, the harmonies are very clear and lush and the low end is tight. <br /> <br />The performance though, is what sets this dvd apart from most, an almost perfect ride through their back catalog with a couple of tunes from \\"Arrival\\" thrown in, \\"Higher Ground\\" being one of the best performances and also one of the best songs they've ever written imo.........you can also amuse yourself by checking out the numerous dirty looks, glares and gestures Neal gives his monitor tech throughout this song and others, I'm not really sure why though because his guitar sound is unbelievable, very loud and crystal clear, if you thought his sound was a tad buried in some of the studio productions, you'll be surprised with this audio mix, he effortlessly re-creates the riffs and leads you all know so well, great stuff. <br /> <br />The other highlight of this show is Steve Augeri's vocals, like several reviewers I actually think he's a better all round singer, maybe doesn't have the high range of Perry but his delivery is markedly more powerful.......he's also a much better live singer in my estimation, puts the coked out Steve Perry performance of \\"Be Good To Yourself\\" on the greatest hits dvd to complete shame. <br /> <br />Deen Castronovo shows everybody why he is one of the most powerful drummers in rock, he hits the skins incredibly hard but with great precision and panache', his performance is exemplary, and he also adds harmony vocals to many of the songs while doing so ! <br /> <br />I would have liked to have seen a documentary or 2 added but thats a minor quibble........definetely looking forward to the new live dvd from the last tour thats supposedly coming out this summer, hopefully it'll be the whole 3 hour show. <br /> <br />All in all a must buy for Journey and indeed, all melodic rock fans out there.

B0000DJZA5|2.0|Despite its flaws, the original \\"Let It Be\\" is a fine album with great songs. I won't say there is nothing worthwhile on \\"Naked\\". For one, the song order makes more sense and works better, and the following 4 tracks are great: the remixed and remastered versions of \\"Dig A Pony\\" (with some minor keyboard fills not heard on the original), \\"Two Of Us\\" (minus opening chatter), \\"I Me Mine\\" (minus strings), and a lovely psychedelic version of \\"Across The Universe\\" (also minus strings). The rest of the album is a mostly shoddy, disappointing affair. It's not revisionism, as someone said; it's a half-assed, money-making toss-off. First of all, some of the songs such as \\"Don't Let Me Down\\" and \\"I've Got A Feeling\\" sound like lethargic rehearsal outtakes, and the latter stops abruptly before the end. \\"Let It Be\\" is not that markedly altered and \\"Get Back\\" sounds exactly the same as the single version (with inferior sound quality - see below). \\"One After 909\\" is remastered from the original, but for some reason the percussion has a \\"shaky\\" sound I find disturbing. \\"For You Blue\\" is okay but definitely not an improvement on the original. And even if you don't like the excess orchestration of \\"The Long and Winding Road\\", this naked version sounds lacking and incomplete. But the worst offense of this CD is that the sound quality on most of the tracks (with the exception of the four I mentioned up front and \\"The Long and Winding Road\\") is terrible, with noticeable hiss and a muddied, muffled sound. I can only assume this was intentional; they could have mixed it out, especially since \\"Get Back\\" is the same as the original single (which sounds much crisper and clearer). If this project had been promoted as a conceptual cousin to the \\"Anthology\\" series then maybe it wouldn't be such a blatant disappointment (but even the outtakes on \\"Anthology\\" from this period had decent sound quality), but implying this is the album the Beatles originally intended is totally misleading. If they had simply remixed and remastered the album and offered as bonus tracks the unorchestrated versions of \\"Across the Universe\\", \\"I Me Mine\\", and \\"Long And Winding Road\\", etc. then it would have been excellent. As for this, I'm glad I didn't spend money on it in the first place.

0802130208|5.0|Personally, I am dumbfounded at some of the claims of the more, shall we say, uptight reviewers found on this page.  To hold an opinion which is contrary to most others' is, of course, perfectly fine, but to claim that those who like the book are simply following suit, that we are simply seeing the \\"emperor's new clothes\\" so as not to be thought stupid, is an affront to the intelligence of the thousands and thousands of readers who have enjoyed this book.  A few things; this is not a comedy in the way an Elmore Leonard novel, or a Douglas Adamas novel, is a comedy.  The comedy is not outright -- that is to say that this is not a novel built around jokes and one-liners -- but that the comedy comes from the characters, the dialogue and the overall outrageousness of its situations.  It is also a misconception that a great main character must be indentifiable with the reader.  The point of the novel is that Ignatius is NOT identifiable to a normal person, just as he cannot identify with normal society.  Were his convictions easy to indentify with, was his position on society easy to swallow and his speech more coloquial he would not be Ignatius J. Reilly.  He is, in fact, one of the snidest, most self-deluded characters I have ever read had the pleasure to read.  He treats his mother terribly, his medieval philosophies sound like the ramblings of an imbecile, and his excuses and complaints could, if they were realized in life, drive someone insane.  It is his good-natured intentions, though, his self-delusions that his shortcomings are in fact blessings and the sheer rediculous nature of his pompousness that makes him such a comic gem of a character.  That we who find this to be true are being compared to the peasants in the age old fable of the emperor's new clothing seems to say a wealth about those who make such claims.  Is it not enough to state one's opinion?  Must one put oneself on a literary pedestal, insulting the intelligence of anyone who disagrees with you?Because you didn't \\"get it\\" does not mean that there was nothing to \\"get.\\"  We got it.  And we who did are in agreement; those new clothes the emperor's sporting are looking damn good. <br /> <br />In summary, there is a reason this book won the Pulitzer Prize and it's not because the judges were too scared to admit they didn't like it.  It's clever, well-written, fast-paced, absorbing and absurd. <br /> <br />Oh, and it's extremely funny, as well.

B000E33VWW|3.0|This movie deserves five stars for acting and four stars for story, but I'm giving it only three stars to indicate how much I wanted to know at least a little more. This film seemed to have it both ways: On the one hand, Capote is a selfish, cynical, manipulative, \\"insincere artist\\"; on the other hand he becomes too emotionally involved with his human subjects and \\"sacrifices his soul\\" writing \\"In Cold Blood.\\" Capote never writes another book and dies of alcoholism years later. Are we supposed to assume a relationship between that book and Capote's decline? There's one line in the movie in which Capote says, \\"This book will change how I see the world, how everyone will see the world.\\" Did it? And did he mean that it would change things for worse? Is it possible that Capote's pre-existing alcoholism was more responsible for his depression and decline than the writing of the book? As I said, there are many unanswered questions and I wish a little more had been shown in this fine film.

B000BTJDGC|3.0|Emily Rose is dead, and the court of law must determine the reason. I know horror film fans would love the film, and some reviewers have found it intelligent, but here I beg to disagree. Yes, the film is not bad, but at the same time I believe somewhere deep inside `The Exorcism of Emily Rose' there is a better film that could have been. <br />  <br />The spooky opening scene effectively introduces us to the world where the supposedly possessed girl was living in a secluded house. Then you are to meet Tom Wilkinson' priest Father Moore who is charged for negligence that the prosecutor (Campbell Scott) says resulted in the death of Emily Rose. Very ambitious and agnostic lawyer Erin Bruner (Laura Linney) takes up the case to defend the priest. <br /> <br />From this point, `The Exorcism of Emily Rose' starts to look like two films in one, one about the courtroom and the other about the death of Emily Rose. <br /> <br />[COURTROOM DRAMA] The film says it is based on the true events, which are in themselves intriguing and intelligent too - `People vs. Exorcist' -- but what you see in the film's two hours you saw somewhere else in other countless courtroom dramas. The film has strong acting from the strong cast, but the characters are terribly flat. Though the frequent flashbacks attempt to hide the fact, the courtroom drama itself is boring and fails to live up to our expectation that we have from the initial scenes. The ambitious female lawyer is working under the slimy guy in suit. New evidence appears and witness appears and disappears as in some other films. The judge is severe (but fair). Haven't we seen them somewhere else before? <br /> <br />[HORROR] Horror part of the film, which is mainly shown in the flashback scenes are slightly better, greatly helped by the very committed acting from Jennifer Carpenter as Emily Rose. She doesn't have to be Linda Blair with her rotating head, but it is easy to imagine she had to endure a lot. The film tries to give us shocks very often always with Ms. Carpenter doing something painful, like bending her body backward, scratching the wallpaper, and eating insects. And of course she has to growl like a demon. It is a cheap trick, some might say, but at least it is not boring. <br /> <br />And whatever the producers might say about the film and its `based on the truth' story, we are attracted to the scary part of the film, and `Emily Rose' is certainly scary. But intelligent debate about the religion and the law? No, even though the film obviously wants to be so.

B000022TSY|5.0|Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper's counter-culture flick \\"Easy Rider\\", like Warren Beatty's \\"Bonnie and Clyde\\", launched the genre of low budget, independent film-making, and is as an important a film as it is a Hollywood milestone..When the studio system faded away (the back-lot assembly line), there was a vacuum in Hollywood and studio heads were gasping for fresh air?..The industry conundrum was, who would fill the void away from candy-corn musicals like \\"The Sound of Music\\", \\"Mary Poppins\\", and \\"Chitty Chitty Bang Bang\\", that were putting movie-goers into a permanent state of snooze, and hemorraging red ink..Box-office receipts were in freefall, an omen revolution was in the air, and a upshift in audience taste was potentially going unrealized?..Columbia Studios figured they had to roll the dice, and test if a youth audience was ready in numbers to buy theatre tickets if original content was exhibited..Dennis Hopper and Peter Fonda were seasoned Hollywood hands that survived the studio wars, and sensed the time was ripe to seize control of their careers by producing new wave content..Collectively, Fonda and Hopper scripted a contemporary \\"noir western\\" screenplay, Fonda as (Wyatt), Hopper as (Billy), two drugstore cowboys, mounted on \\"iron horses\\" on an existentialist journey to find America, that reflected the angst, paranoia, and prejudices permeating the Johnson/Nixon Viet Nam War era..\\"Easy Rider\\" is a biker odyssey, and the end-game is to get to New Orleans and \\"experience\\" Mardi Gras before the apocalyptic collapse of culture, an Edenistic premise..See the movie now, and excuse the dated 60's precepts..Realize the movie was an emboldened out-of-the-box move by its creators and Columbia..View the movie in context, and you will overlook its rough edges, and cardboard cut-out stereo-types..The movie occupies a sacred place in indie filmmaking, and paved the way for maverick film-makers like Robert Altman, Peter Bogdanovich, and William Friedkin, meaning there are films today that stand on the shoulders of \\"Easy Rider\\", as primitive as the 16mm. film might seem relative to today's digitally enhanced standards..The film proved there was enormous profitability in \\"new realism\\", and ushered in packaging a rock soundtrack to accentuate the picture, at the time a sound-breaking strategy.

0060899190|5.0|best book ever made. <br />it draws you in and makes you feel one with the people who made the secrets!
0808514121|5.0|Steinbeck's reflection on the story of Genesis in the Bible is both intricate and reflective. The story serves to illustrate common themes and issues embedded within the family structure and society as well. He is also able to make a point about the existence of free will in each individual's destiny.     One of the aspects that make this book quintessentially American is the diversity of the characters' qualities, both good and bad. Lee is perhaps the most uniquely complex figure in the story-he is not only a role model and parental-type figure for both the Trask boys and Abra, but deeply philosophical about man's existence in life, and the struggles he faces. Lee really is the force that keeps the Trask family afloat when the strains of life hit several members, namely Adam. He is able to single-handedly pull Adam out of his disillusionment with Cathy. Lee is so poignant to the novel because he reaches others at a level that most fail to reach, and he helps Adam begin life anew with his two sons. Cathy represents one of the darkest and malicious characters in literature, and is seemingly at the opposite spectrum of Lee-she represents destructiveness, cruelty, thoughtlessness, and cynicism. Cathy (later Kate) is not only hurtful to others around her, but there are times when she literally shuns goodness when it is in close proximity to her. Even her physical condition, in which she hates to be around light, is representative of her sinister mentality about the world and her rejection of benevolence. Samuel Hamilton is depicted as a great man, a go-getter who captures the attention of his listeners because of his stories and his great vision for invention. Samuel is seemingly underappreciated by most in the novel with the exception of Lee and Adam, who cherish his knowledge. Samuel's impact on both Lee and Adam come much later in the story and after much reflection on their part.     Another compelling aspect of Steinbeck's work is the definition and reflection on the idea of wealth. In many instances, \\"physical\\" wealth means very little. Will Hamilton is a character who believes in the principle of attaining wealth, but is very one-dimensional. Cal first sees wealth as an access to gain favor with his father, but then winds up rejecting this idea, and literally burning the money he had acquired. Kate gains a good deal of money from her brothel business, but it is money that brings neither happiness nor goodness to others. In direct contrast to these characters, Samuel Hamilton and Lee embody a \\"spiritual\\" wealth in the novel. Samuel, for instance, works hard, invents many things, and collect very few material rewards, yet his friendship is the most significant to others. Lee, similarly, is not wealthy, and comes to terms with his role as a giver rather than one who needs to acquire monetary gains. He seems to accept this role, and even rejects the one chance he does have to go to San Francisco and begin a business adventure. Steinbeck's larger message could be that the notion of \\"wealth\\" is more symbolic than physical.     Perhaps the most consequential issue explored is that of free will-that we are all in charge of our own destinies despite our blood or our stations in life. This is revealed in Lee's explanation of the phrase \\"thou mayest\\", and the idea of choosing our own destination-good or evil-is illustrated most significantly in the character of Cal Trask-who wavers between choosing good and evil for much of the novel.     This is a thoroughly powerful book, perhaps one of the forgotten treasures in literature. Steinbeck is able to draw you in, and although this novel is quite lengthy (over six hundred pages in length), it is a captivating story with complex ideas, characters and symbols.
B00005JLEU|4.0|The first rule of watching this movie is simple: Just because something is animated it doesn't mean it's always for kids. Spirited Away is best for adults and older teens. Little ones will be disturbed. The best way to describe is that it's sort of like Wizard of OZ without music and set in fantasy Japan with ugly monsters.  <br /> <br />Instead of just getting home to Kansas the heroine has to save her parents and then make it back to the world of humans.  Except for one moment of stupidity and greed that gets the show started there is nothing interesting about the parents. This is a pretty good idea because their blandness is a huge contrast from the spirit world that Sen must go to to save them.  <br /> <br />Sen is a spunky kid with a kind heart. She's brave, resourceful and eventually wins over the cranky employees of the spirit world bathhouse. The bathhouse is a vacation spot for some incredible creatures. The huge radish spirit, silent and semi nude but wearing a juanty hat, was a standout. I've never liked raishes and now I definitely don't want any.  Most of the creatures are grotesque. I mean really disgusting, really creepy and that's one reason why the little kids should be put to bed before you watch the movie. There's also a great deal of chunky  vomit all over the place.   <br /> <br />The villianess witch is fantastic. She's cruel, funny and ugly. She's that nasty teacher who made your fifth grade absolute hell. She's that spiteful old biddy down the street who used to threaten to call the police if you walked to close to her lawn. She's that babysitter who didn't let you watch TV and sent you to your room until your parents came back. In short, she's a classic childhood fear figure. The witch does have one virtue. She loves her giant baby and that will be a huge help to Sen and her quest.  <br /> <br />I liked Spirited Away but I did think it's way too long and the ending where Sen FINALLY leaves with her boring and ungrateful parents (because theyhave no memory of ever being pigs under a spell) is an emotional let down.

B00005RIXP|5.0|I have seen 4 versions of Tosca, and this is the first one that left me a favorable impression of the title charachter. In the 3 other versions I saw, including one at the Met, the Toscas came off as cranky naggers, not passionate lovers.  I saw Marton in the Met's Turandot, and found her rather stiff.  But, here in Sydney, her body language comes alive, and you will instantly feel the intense jealousy that Tosca has for her lover. Until now, I mostly liked only the two famous arias by Cavardossi.  Now,I finally know why this opera has enjoyed worldwide appeal for so many years.  Brava, Eva Marton.

B00008OLYN|5.0|I just entered the wonderful world of Opeth by purchasing their latest release Ghost Reveries. Ghost Reveries is great, but Damnation is beyond even that.   <br />The first thing that makes this album so good is the crystal-clear production.  This album probably has the most precise and wonderfully textured production I have ever heard.  The producer, Steve Wilson, is an absolute genius who might as well be the 5th member of this band.  His vocal harmonies and keyboards are an extremely tasteful touch to the band's sound as well as his mastering of the CD. And the lead guitarist provides very emotional and tasteful soloing throughout, as well as adding the necessary electric guitar parts. <br />The whole album is great, not a single weak track. But even this may be pushing it because it's that hard to place one song over another.  Each song, with its acoustic touches, transitions so smoothly to the next track that this CD really requires it to be listened to from beginning to end.  However, this CD is a bit different from Opeth's other albums.  If you enjoy this kind of sound combined with a very heavy blend of metal, then I'd continue exploring the restof their catalogue.  But don't let this detract you though, their melodic elements remain in tact throughout and they are far beyond any other modern metal band today, with maybe the exception of Dream Theater (who I also recommend).  With that note, buy this album!
